Module lanat
Package lanat

Class Argument<Type extends ArgumentType<TInner>,TInner>

java.lang.Object
lanat.Argument<Type,TInner>
Type Parameters:
Type - the ArgumentType subclass that will parse the value passed to the argument
TInner - the actual type of the value passed to the argument
All Implemented Interfaces:
CommandUser, ErrorCallbacks<TInner,Argument<Type,TInner>>, ErrorContainer<ArgumentTypeError>, GroupUser, MultipleNamesAndDescription, NamedWithDescription, Resettable
public class Argument<Type extends ArgumentType<TInner>,TInner> extends Object implements ErrorContainer<ArgumentTypeError>, ErrorCallbacks<TInner,Argument<Type,TInner>>, Resettable, CommandUser, GroupUser, MultipleNamesAndDescription

Argument

An Argument specifies a value that the user can introduce to the command. This value will be parsed by the specified ArgumentType each time the Argument is used. Once finished parsing, the value may be retrieved by using ParseResult.get(String...) on the ParseResult object returned by ArgumentParser.parse(CLInput).

An Argument can be created using the factory methods available, like createOfActionType(String...).



Example:

An Argument with the names "name" and 'n' that will parse an integer value. In order to create an Argument, you need to call any of the static factory methods available, like createOfActionType(String...). These methods will return an ArgumentBuilder object, which can be used to specify the Argument's properties easily. 

 
     Argument.create(new IntegerArgumentType(), "name", "n");
     Argument.create(new IntegerArgumentType()).names("name", "n");

Argument usage

The argument can be used in the following ways:
  • Specifying the whole name with the prefix: "--name 32" or "-name 32".

    An equals sign can be used instead of a space: "--name=32" or "-name=32".

  • Since the argument in the example above has a single character name, this is also possible: "-n32".
See Also:
  • Command.addArgument(Argument)
  • Group
  • ArgumentParser

      The type of this argument. This is the subParser that will be used to parse the value/s this argument should receive.

    • setPositional

      public void setPositional(boolean positional)
      Marks the argument as positional. This means that the value of this argument may be specified directly without indicating a name of this argument. The positional place where it should be placed is defined by the order of creation of the argument definitions.
      • Note that an argument marked as positional can still be used by specifying a name.

    • isPositional

      public boolean isPositional()
      Returns true if this argument is positional.
      Returns:
      true if this argument is positional.
      See Also:

    • setPrefix

      public void setPrefix(@NotNull Argument.Prefix prefix)
      Specify the prefix of this argument. By default, this is Argument.Prefix.DEFAULT. If this argument is used in an argument name list (-abc), the prefix that will be valid is any against all the arguments specified in that name list.

      Note that, for ease of use, the prefixes defined in Argument.Prefix.COMMON_PREFIXES are also valid.

      Parameters:
      prefix - the prefix that should be used for this argument.
      See Also:
      • Argument.Prefix

    • getPrefix

      @NotNull public Argument.Prefix getPrefix()
      Returns the prefix of this argument.
      Returns:
      the prefix of this argument.

    • setUnique

      public void setUnique(boolean unique)
      Specifies that this argument has priority over other arguments, even if they are required. This means that if an argument in a command is set as required, but one argument with unique was used, then the unused required argument will not throw an error.

      Note that if a unique argument is used, no other argument will be allowed to be used.

    • isUnique

      public boolean isUnique()
      Returns true if this argument has priority over other arguments, even if they are required.
      Returns:
      true if this argument has priority over other arguments, even if they are required.
      See Also:
      • setUnique(boolean)

    • setDefaultValue

      public void setDefaultValue(@Nullable TInner value)
      The value that should be used if the user does not specify a value for this argument. If the argument does not accept values, this value will be ignored.
      Parameters:
      value - the value that should be used if the user does not specify a value for this argument. If the value is null, then no default value will be used.

      public void setNames(@NotNull @NotNull List<@NotNull String> names)
      Set the names of this object. This is useful if you want the same argument to be used with multiple different names.

      Single character names can be used in argument name lists (e.g. -abc), each alphabetic character being an argument name, that is, -a -b -c.

      Specified by:

    • checkMatch

      public boolean checkMatch(@NotNull @NotNull String name)
      Checks if this argument matches the given name, including the prefix.

      For example, if the prefix is '-' and the argument has the name "help", this method will return true if the name is "--help".

      Parameters:
      name - the name to check
      Returns:
      true if the name matches, false otherwise.

    • equals

      public boolean equals(@NotNull @NotNull Object obj)
      Returns true if the argument specified by the given name is equal to this argument.

      Equality is determined by the argument's name and the command it belongs to.

    • compareByPriority

      public static int compareByPriority(@NotNull @NotNull Argument<?,?> first, @NotNull @NotNull Argument<?,?> second)
      Compares two arguments by the synopsis view priority order.

      Order: Positional > Unique > Required > Optional.

      Parameters:
      first - the first argument to compare
      second - the second argument to compare
      Returns:
      0 if both arguments are equal, -1 if the first argument goes before the second, 1 if the second goes before the first.

    • sortByPriority

    • setMinimumDisplayErrorLevel

      public void setMinimumDisplayErrorLevel(@NotNull @NotNull ErrorLevel level)
      Description copied from interface: ErrorContainer
      The minimum error level that will be displayed to the user. All errors with a level lower than this will be ignored. For example, If this is set to ErrorLevel.INFO, then errors including ErrorLevel.INFO, ErrorLevel.WARNING, and ErrorLevel.ERROR) will be displayed, but ErrorLevel.DEBUG will not.
      Specified by:
      setMinimumDisplayErrorLevel in interface ErrorContainer<Type extends ArgumentType<TInner>>
      Parameters:
      level - The minimum error level that will be displayed to the user.

    • setMinimumExitErrorLevel

      public void setMinimumExitErrorLevel(@NotNull @NotNull ErrorLevel level)
      Description copied from interface: ErrorContainer
      The minimum error level that will cause the program to exit. All errors with a level equal to or higher than this will cause the program to exit. For example, if this is set to ErrorLevel.WARNING, then errors with a level of ErrorLevel.WARNING or ErrorLevel.ERROR will cause the program to exit.
      Specified by:
      setMinimumExitErrorLevel in interface ErrorContainer<Type extends ArgumentType<TInner>>
      Parameters:
      level - The minimum error level that will cause the program to exit.

    • setOnErrorCallback

      public void setOnErrorCallback(@Nullable @Nullable Consumer<@NotNull Argument<Type,TInner>> callback)
      Specify a function that will be called if an error occurs when parsing this argument.

      Note that this callback is only called if the error was dispatched by this argument's type. That is, if the argument, for example, is required, and the user does not specify a value, an error will be thrown, but this callback will not be called, as the error was not dispatched by this argument's type.

      Specified by:
      setOnErrorCallback in interface ErrorCallbacks<Type extends ArgumentType<TInner>,TInner>
      Parameters:
      callback - the function that will be called if an error occurs when parsing this argument.

    • setOnOkCallback

      public void setOnOkCallback(@Nullable @Nullable Consumer<@NotNull TInner> callback)
      Specify a function that will be called with the value introduced by the user.

      By default this callback is called only if all commands succeed, but you can change this behavior with Command.setCallbackInvocationOption(Command.CallbackInvocationOption)

      Specified by:
      setOnOkCallback in interface ErrorCallbacks<Type extends ArgumentType<TInner>,TInner>
      Parameters:
      callback - the function that will be called with the value introduced by the user.

    • invokeCallbacks

      public void invokeCallbacks()

    • removePrefix

      @NotNull public static @NotNull String removePrefix(@NotNull @NotNull String name, char character)
      Removes the prefix from the given name. If the name does not have the prefix, then it will be returned as is.

      Example: removePrefix("--name", '-') or removePrefix("-name", '-') will return "name".

      Parameters:
      name - the name to remove the prefix from
      character - the prefix character to remove
      Returns:
      the name without the prefix
